---
layout: default
title: "fastascan"
---

```fastascan``` is the name of a tool that we had to create in the MSc in bioinformatics as an assignment for a Unix/algorithmics course. This was one midterm assignment after approximately 2 months using bash. 

The purpose of this script is to design a tool that detects the .fa or .fasta files in an user-specified folder, does a summary of the files in the folder, and then an individual report containing the number of sequences, the number of amino acids/nucleotides in the whole file, specifying if the file is a symbolic link, and detecting if the file contains nucleotide or amino acid sequences. 

The user can specify the folder to search in, and also if they want the first and last "n" lines of the file to be shown. If the number of lines of the file is smaller than 2n, the whole file is shown. The format to use the tool is ```fastascan [folder] [number_of_lines]```. If the user doesn't specify the folder to search, it will use by default the current directory. If the user doesn't specify the number of lines, it won't show any content of the file. If the 1st argument is an integer, and there is no 2nd argument, it will interpret the 1st as the number of lines that the user wants to see, and will search in the current directory.

# Example

## Files
For an example, I created a folder with 4 different files (2 contain protein sequences in fasta format, 1 contains nucleic acid sequences in fasta format, and another one is a plain text without format). You can click them to see the content.

## Output

This is the output of ```fastascan``` using the default settings (without specifying directory or number of lines, meaning that it will search in the current directory and not show any content from the files):

<details>
	
<summary>Click to toggle the output</summary>
<pre>

suarezalvarez🐉 ~/sequences_example $ fastascan

!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!IMPORTANT INFORMATION!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
This program uses 2 arguments: the directory and the number of lines of each file to show.
If you only specify one of them, it will be interpreted as the number of lines if this argument is an integer, and as the directory if it is a text string.

This program considers a .fasta or .fa file to be a nucleotide (RNA or DNA) sequence if the content of A, C, T, G, U and N (upper or lower case) in the sequences contained in the file is greater or equal than 90%. If this condition is not fulfilled, the file will automatically be considered a protein sequence file.

This program considers the first word (delimited by spaces) after the ">" symbol in a fasta header as the identifier of the sequence.

This program uses 2 arguments: the directory and the number of lines of each file to show.
If you only specify one of them, it will be interpreted as the number of lines if this argument is an integer, and as the directory if it is a text string.

This program considers a .fasta or .fa file to be a nucleotide (RNA or DNA) sequence if the content of A, C, T, G, U and N (upper or lower case) in the sequences contained in the file is greater or equal than 90%. If this condition is not fulfilled, the file will automatically be considered a protein sequence file.

This program considers the first word (delimited by spaces) after the ">" symbol in a fasta header as the identifier of the sequence.
